title: Catholic Teachers Support Scheme secures building plots for members
text:
13 July 2015 23:00 CET Catholic Teachers Support Scheme secures building plots for members By GNA 
Kumasi, July 13, GNA - The Ashanti Regional Catholic Teachers Support Scheme, a Credit Union, has procured 350 building plots for members to enable them live in the comfort of their own houses after their mandatory retirement from public service. 
The beneficiaries had through a friendly repayment scheme, paid for the building plots, located at Abrankese-Nyameani, Atwima Wiredu and Esaase, all in the region. 
The Board Chairman of the Scheme, Mr George Kwadwo Tuffour, announced this at the Third Triennial General Meeting of the Scheme in Kumasi. 
He recounted that the scheme which was formed 10 years ago with only with few teachers, could now boast of 3,548 members, aimed at helping to improve their financial status. 
Touching on the financial performance of the Scheme, the Board Chairman said the total assets of the scheme increased from GH¢ 8,623,255.65 in 2014 to GH¢ 6,519,730.99 in 2013 representing 32 per cent. 
Mr Tuffour said the Scheme, however, posted decline in net surplus from GH¢ 430,686.50 in 2013 to GH¢ 287,373.21 in 2014, representing 33.28 per cent. 
He attributed the reduction to the substantial amount of Gh¢ 634,758.42 which was used to pay dividends to members of the scheme. 
Mr Gabriel Agyare-Gyamfi, the General Manager of the Scheme, said it was refreshing that the Scheme which operated from a small room when it started 10 years ago, had now been able to build its own office complex. 
He implored members to intensify efforts at getting more people onto the Scheme, so that they could also benefit from its operations. 
A former Ashanti Regional Manager of the Catholic Education Unit, Mr Polycarp Assafuah, reminded teachers of the need to develop the culture of savings from their incomes, irrespective of how meagre their salaries were. 
'You do not need to wait till you get closer to retirement before you begin to plan towards saving to build their house', he counseled. 
Most Reverend John Yaw Afoakwa, Catholic Bishop of Obuasi, advised management of the scheme to adopt prudent measures to ensure efficiency and the proper utilization of resources. 
He urged the staff of the scheme to uphold good customer service, to promote good relationship with members and the management. 
GNA
